t: Proverbs 20
On Life and Conduct
Wine*pn is a mocker, strong drink a brawler, And*ln whoever is intoxicated by it is not wise.
The*ln terror of a king is like the growling of a lion; He*ln who provokes him to anger forfeits his own life.
Keeping*ln away from strife is an honor for a man, But*ln any fool will quarrel.
The*ln sluggard does not plow after the autumn, So*ln he begs during the harvest and has nothing.
A*ln plan in the heart of a man is like*i deep water, But*ln a man of understanding draws it out.
Many*ln a man proclaims his own loyalty, But*ln who can find a trustworthy man?
A*ln righteous man who walks in his integrity— How*ln blessed are his sons after him.
A*ln king who sits on the throne of justice Disperses*ln all evil with his eyes.
Who*ln can say, “I have cleansed my heart, I*ln am pure from my sin”?
Differing*ln weights and differing measures, Both*ln of them are abominable to the Lord.*s
It*ln is by his deeds that a lad distinguishes himself If*ln his conduct is pure and right.
The*ln hearing ear and the seeing eye, The*ln Lord*s has made both of them.
Do*ln not love sleep, or you will become poor; Open*ln your eyes, and*i you will be satisfied with food.
“Bad,*ln bad,” says the buyer, But*ln when he goes his way, then he boasts.
There*ln is gold, and an abundance of jewels; But*ln the lips of knowledge are a more precious thing.
Take*ln his garment when he becomes surety for a stranger; And*ln for foreigners, hold him in pledge.
Bread*ln obtained by falsehood is sweet to a man, But*ln afterward his mouth will be filled with gravel.
Prepare*ln plans by consultation, And*ln make war by wise guidance.
He*ln who goes about as a slanderer reveals secrets, Therefore*ln do not associate with a gossip.
He*ln who curses his father or his mother, His*ln lamp will go out in time of darkness.
An*ln inheritance gained hurriedly at the beginning Will*ln not be blessed in the end.
Do*ln not say, “I will repay evil”; Wait*ln for the Lord,*s and He will save you.
Differing*ln weights are an abomination to the Lord,*s And*ln a false scale is not good.
Man’s*ln steps are ordained*i by the Lord,*s How*ln then can man understand his way?
It*ln is a trap for a man to say rashly, “It is holy!” And*ln after the vows to make inquiry.
A*ln wise king winnows the wicked, And*ln drives the threshing*i wheel over them.
The*ln spirit of man is the lamp of the Lord,*s Searching*ln all the innermost parts of his being.
Loyalty*ln and truth preserve the king, And*ln he upholds his throne by righteousness.
The*ln glory of young men is their strength, And*ln the honor of old men is their gray hair.
Stripes*ln that wound scour away evil, And*ln strokes reach*i the innermost parts.
